modules.description: This module provides functions for string and file manipulation, including checking if a string starts with a prefix, converting a string to a list of characters, reading a file into a list of lines, and writing a string to a file. It works with basic data types such as strings, character lists, and file paths. Use cases include parsing text files, processing string data, and handling file input/output operations.

This module converts parsed mathematical structures into LaTeX code for web rendering. It handles operations like generating LaTeX commands from parameter lists, recalculating environments for alignment and equation blocks, and reconstructing full LaTeX output from structured data. It directly works with lists of parsed structures representing mathematical expressions and environments.

This module processes glossary files, parsing entries and storing them in a hash table for generating HTML output. It handles string manipulation, file parsing, and glossary initialization, working with strings and string lists as primary data structures. Concrete use cases include extracting glossary terms and definitions from text files and converting them into HTML format.

Transforms a parsed document AST into structured HTML files with proper formatting and navigation. It handles hierarchical content like chapters and sections, generating tables of contents and applying styles. Directly used to convert TeX source files into complete, readable HTML documents.

This module parses LaTeX book content into an abstract syntax tree (AST) composed of commands and structures. It processes strings into recursive data types like `cmd` and `structure`, representing LaTeX elements such as chapters, sections, environments, and inline math. Concrete use cases include transforming LaTeX source into structured data for HTML rendering or extracting document metadata like title and author from the preamble.

This module processes LaTeX book content into structured HTML, converting parsed mathematical expressions and document hierarchies into web-ready output. It supports parsing LaTeX into an AST, transforming math structures into aligned LaTeX for rendering, and generating HTML files with navigation and styling. Key data types include parsed structures, command trees, and glossary entries, with operations for file I/O, string manipulation, and HTML generation. Examples include converting a TeX file into a navigable HTML document, extracting and formatting glossary terms, and rendering aligned equations for web display.
